IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: CBIA Education Foundation (CBIA EF) helps to develop a skilled workforce in Connecticut. It accomplishes this mission by strengthening educational policies and practices, stimulating career development and exploration, and promoting job training to match employer needs.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The mission of the CBIA Education Foundation is to help develop a skilled, knowledgable workforce in Connecticut.
IRS990.Desc: CBIA Education Foundation (CBIAEF) is the statewide business partner for the Connecticut Community Colleges College of Technology Regional Center for Next Generation Manufacturing (RCNGM), funded by the National Science Foundation. The goal of this program is to ensure that classroom learning reflects the realities of the 21st century manufacturing workplace. CBIAEF administered a teacher externship program, placing high school and community college instructors at local manufacturers for four weeks each summer. CBIAEF also organized student/teacher expos to promote manufacturing and technology careers and college programs, and several workshops for teachers and guidance counselors to learn more about local manufacturers and the advance manufacturing program at the community colleges.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: The goals of the NSF Mechanical and Manufacturing Technologies for Energy and Sustainability (MET2) Program are 1) develop engineering and business skills-based curriculum, including technical, professional and entrepreneurial skills, for engineering and technical disciplines; 2) engage community college and university students to solve real-world challenges in a team based learning environment; 3) engage technical high school students to improve the career pipeline in technology and engineering disciplines; and 4) provide professional development for teachers and faculty to use MET2 curriculum both online and in person.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: CBIAEF is the sector intermediary for the Transportation, Distribution, and Logistics (TDL) Workforce Partnership, funded by the Workforce Solutions Collaborative of Metro Hartford. CBIAEF brings together business, education, labor, and workforce development partners to develop and implement solutions to increase the pipeline of skilled TDL workers. Services provided to low- income, low-skill job seekers in the greater Hartford area included financial and case management support for students enrolled in commercial driver license (CDL) training programs, CDL training scholarships, and financial literacy connections. Employer services included job seeker referrals and wage subsidies for hiring and training newly licensed graduates.

ProgSrvcAccomActyOtherGrp.Desc: CBIAEF's other program activities in support of the organization's mission.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CBIA pays its president, secretary, and treasurer an amount equivalent to a 401k match on income in excess of qualified plan compensation limits. These amounts are grossed up for taxes and reported as W2 income.

The compensation for CBIAEF's president, secretary, and treasurer are set by the Compensation Committee. The members of this committee are CBIAEF's president, chair of the board of directors, two vice-chairs and immediate past chair. The committee follows a documented compensation philosophy. The committee uses data provided by an independent compensation consultant to establish appropriate compensation and benefit plans for these employees. The committee also administers the variable pay plan for these employees.
CBIAEF's president and treasurer participate in two non-qualified pension plans. These plans were frozen July 1, 2013.

CBIAEF and its related organizations (CBIA and CBIA Service Corporation) have a variable pay plan for selected employees. Participants in the plan have a targeted percentage of annual salary for their variable compensation. These targets are increased or decreased based on each employee's achievement of individual goals, and are also adjusted based on the combined revenues of CBIAEF, CBIA and CBIA Service Corporation.
Some participants in the variable pay plan described in Schedule J Part I Line 5 have individual goals that include the combined net income of CBIA, CBIAEF and CBIA Service Corporation.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CBIAEF's compensation committee reviewed the Form 990 at its December 2018 meeting. The members of this committee are CBIAEF's president, the chair of CBIAEF's board of directors, the two vice-chairs and immediate past chair. The Form 990 is made available to other board members upon request.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: All employees, officers and board members are required to complete a conflict of interest statement annually. CBIAEF's secretary reviews these statements and works with management and the board of directors to resolve any conflicts.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The compensation for CBIAEF's president, secretary and treasurer is set by CBIAEF's compensation committee annually. The committee reviews salary surveys and data provided by an independent compensation consultant to establish appropriate compensation and benefit plans for these employees. The committee adheres to a documented compensation philosophy. The committee also administers the variable pay plans for these employees by reviewing objectives and benchmarks, evaluating performance, and approving awards.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CBIAEF's governing documents are filed with the Connecticut Secretary of State and are a matter of public record. CBIAEF's financial statements and conflict of interest policy are available upon request.
Grant consultants for training and curriculum development.

TransactionsRelatedOrgGrp.MethodOfAmountDeterminationTxt: Amount contributed by CBIA to enable CBIAEF to meet its financial and business obligations.
CBIAEF shares office space which is leased by CBIA Service Corporation. CBIAEF reimburses CBIA Service Corporation of its share of the rent and other office expenses.

CBIAEF Executive Director and program staff are paid by CBIA Service Corporation. In addition, CBIAEF shares other employees which are paid by CBIA Service Corporation. CBIA Service Corporation charges CBIAEF for their share of the salary and benefits for these employees.
Cash paid to CBIA Service Corporation to reimburse salary and office expenses.
